did.unittitle: Mabou Mines Archive

physdesc.extent: in 276 record cartons, 23.5 manuscript boxes, 11 small flat boxes, 48 oversize flat boxes, 68 flat file folders, 13 film cans, 1 box binder, 1 rolled storage tube, and 11 oversize objects.

did.abstract: Beginning in 1970 Mabou Mines helped revolutionize experimental theatre in the United States and contributed to an international movement in avant-garde, postmodern theatre. The Mabou Mines create multi-media performances utilizing both existing texts and building performances utilizing a pastiche style that draws on a variety of sources. The materials in the collection document this creative process and the administrative functions necessary to maintain and promote the company.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Fales Library purchased the Mabou Mines Archive from the Mabou Mines Development Foundation in 2003. In 2019 a trunk of posters was located in the repository, accessioned separately, and integrated into the collection as Series XV.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p:
Mabou Mines is a collaborative, avant-garde theater company based in New York City. Founded in 1970, the company took its name from an old mining town in northern Nova Scotia, near where founding members JoAnne Akalaitis, Lee Breuer, Philip Glass, Ruth Maleczech, and David Warrilow, developed The Red Horse Animation, the group's first original performance piece. Since then Mabou Mines has produced scores of plays, collaborated with well-known writers, musicians, visual artists, and filmmakers, garnered heaps of critical praise and awards, and performed around the globe, cementing its reputation as an innovative force in the theater world. The company's official website is maboumines.org.
Lee Breuer and Ruth Maleczech met studying theater at UCLA in the late 1950s. Around 1960, the couple hitchhiked to San Francisco to participate in the city's active theater scene. Working at the San Francisco Actor's Workshop and the San Francisco Mime Troupe they met Bill Raymond, and at the San Francisco Tape Music Center they met JoAnne Akalaitis. In 1964 Akalaitis moved to New York City but left for Paris soon after with composer (and future husband) Philip Glass. The following year Breuer and Maleczech left San Francisco for Europe. The two couples met up while traveling in Greece, went back to Paris, and with actor David Warrilow, began to work on staging Samuel Beckett's Play. It premiered at the American Cultural Center in 1967. It was also in Paris that the group first met actor Frederick Neumann. In 1969, back in New York with Glass, Akalaitis wrote the others in Paris suggesting they form a theater group in New York.
"Mabou Mines came together as a group to create formal works that would explore language and acting. They had a strong desire to collectively exercise complete artistic control over the work."1 Influenced especially by Jerzy Grotowski's teaching and Beckett's work, Mabou Mines went on to produce experimental theater pieces like Breuer's Red Horse Animationpieces that resulted from intense collaboration and improvisation, and incorporated elements of visual art, dance, mime, puppetry, and music. Arc Welding Piece (1972), for example, featured an artist using an arc welder to make cuts in a large piece of metal, while actors expressed various states of emotion, their faces enlarged by magnifying lenses. In 1974, Fred Neumann joined the group to work on Breuer's second "Animation," The B. Beaver Animation. Bill Raymond joined shortly thereafter.
In its early years, Mabou Mines moved easily between the art world and the theater, often performing in galleries as well as stages. But its work with Beckett's writing firmly situated the group within a theatrical context. "Mabou Mines has produced eight pieces by Samuel Beckett [ Cascando, Come and Go, Company, Imagination Dead Imagine, The Lost Ones, Mercier and Camier, Play, Worstward Ho], six of which have been world premieres of texts not originally written for the theatre. These productions have led to Mabou Mines being considered one of the foremost interpreters of Beckett's work."2 After an early residency at La Mama Experimental Theatre Club in New York, the company began performing at Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, and other venues in New York and elsewhere.
From the beginning, creative roles were fluid and collaboration was key, but Lee Breuer served as the company's primary director. In 1975 however, Akalaitis directed Cascando and opened the door for other members to take on new roles, for the company to expand, and for multiple projects to come together simultaneously. Akalaitis went on to direct Dressed Like an Egg (1977) and Southern Exposure (1979), and wrote and directed Dead End Kids (1980); Neumann directed Mercier and Camier (1979); Maleczech directed Vanishing Pictures (1980). Other performers worked with Mabou Mines, including L.B. Dallas, Linda Hartinian, Ellen McElduff, Greg Mehrten, Terry O'Reilly, and B-St. John Schofield.
The company steadily expanded its repertoire and continued its tradition of collaboration, working with talented performers and artists, including composers Bob Telson, John Zorn, Pauline Oliveros, and David Byrne. Mabou Mines has adapted works by Shakespeare ( Lear, 1990), Franz Xaver Kroetz ( Through the Leaves, 1984; Help Wanted, 1986), Philip K. Dick ( Flow My Tears, The Policeman Said, 1985), and Bertolt Brecht ( In the Jungle of Cities, 1991). The company has toured extensively in the United States and abroad.
Mabou Mines has remained committed to its ideal of complete artistic control. "All decisions, artistic and administrative, large and small, are made by the company members, and each member functions variously as producer, designer, actor, writer, or director for the other. Additionally all participate as members of the Board of Directors."3
As the company stated in a 1990 press kit, "The artistic purpose of Mabou Mines has been and remains the creation of new theatre pieces from original texts and the theatrical use of existing texts staged from a specific point of view. Each member is encouraged to pursue his or her artistic vision by initiating and collaborating on a wide range of projects of varying styles, developing them from initial concept to final performance. This process is intense and often lengthy. While the director of a Mabou Mines work is responsible for its concept and its basic structure, the ultimate production reflects the concerns and the artistic input of all its collaborators."4
References: 1. Unknown author, unpublished manuscript. A history of Mabou Mines through 1989. 2. Mabou Mines, company history included in press kit, 1990. 3. Mabou Mines website, maboumines.org. 4. Mabou Mines, company history included in press kit, 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Mabou Mines Archive contains an extremely diverse array of materials that comprehensively document the first 25 years of Mabou Mines, the New York City-based avant-garde theater company. The collection includes materials that document the innovative methods used by Mabou Mines to create unique theatrical adaptations from existing, often classical texts. Collaboration is a key element of Mabou Mines's artistic vision. All decisions, artistic and administrative, large and small, are made by the company members, and each member functions variously as producer, designer, actor, writer, or director. Additionally, all participate as members of the Board of Directors. Materials in the archive reflect this intensely collaborative environment.

The collection contains a wealth of production materials that document all aspects of theatrical production. It includes invaluable administrative records that reflect how the organization sustained, promoted, and financially supported its mission. Also included are scripts, programs, photographic documentation, production books and touring files, and extensive video documentation of most productions. As one of the leading interpreters of the literary works of Samuel Beckett, the collection contains correspondence between Beckett and Ruth Maleczech and Lee Breuer.
Known for their innovative incorporation of technology in theatrical productions, the Mabou Mines Archive contains extensive film, video, and audio production elements and supporting documentation.

The collection will be of interest to researchers working in the areas of avant-garde performance, performance art, experimental theatre, New York theater history and artistic collaborations, as well as to researchers examining the contemporary intersection between experimental theater, mime, music, poetry and the visual arts.
Numerous oversize items found at the end of each of the series include design plots, posters, oversize printed matter and other promotional materials housed in boxes and map cases.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: For the most part, materials are arranged alphabetically. Production related materials are arranged alphabetically by production title with subseries for materials documenting different performance venues arranged chronogically. Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by correspondent. Photographs and slides are arranged alphabetically by the name of the subject or production title that the materials document. Scripts and production books are arranged alphabetically by production title. Videorecordings are also arranged alphabetically by production title.
Series XII: Financial Files, Grants and Development and Series XIII: Administrative Files were processed at the box level.
All efforts were made to preserve the original arrangement of the collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open to researchers. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: One copy of the comic book adaptation of Red Horse Animation was removed and catalogued individually in the Fales Library's Downtown Print and Periodicals Collection. This item has been cataloged in Bobcat, NYU's online catalog.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); Mabou Mines Archive; MSS 133; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Access to some audiovisual materials in this collection is available through digitized access copies. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact special.collections@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: In August 2017, four items were prepared to be moved to offsite art storage in September 2017. In 2019, 108 posters were located in a trunk and surveyed for preservation needs. Rolled posters were humidified and dried under weight, tears were mended, adhesive residue was reduced, and tape was trimmed. These posters were integrated into the collection as a new series (Series XV) in accordance with the collection's existing arrangement structure. In 2023 45 duplicate VHS were deaccessioned and returned to the donor.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: In 2019 it was determined that 45 VHS that were part of accession 2003-133 and used as access copies were in fact duplicates copies of original collection material. In 2023 these duplicates were returned to Mabou Mines.

did.unittitle: Series I: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains documentation of the formation of the company and its early history, fan mail and other matters. Of particular interest are letters between the playwright Samuel Beckett and company members. The series also includes correspondence with Ellen Stewart, artistic director of LaMaMa E.T.C.

Series II: Programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series comprises the original programs for performances of most of Mabou Mines' productions, and several Mabou Mines-related productions. Series II is arranged alphabetically by production and then chronologically by performance. In general, if a program lists more than one production, the first-billed production is given precedence. Additional programs and program production elements (descriptions, cast biographies, artwork, etc.) can be found in Series III and Series VIII.

Series III: Production Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p:
This series comprises the production files for many of Mabou Mines' stage productions; for Re-Cher-Chez and Mabou Mines/Suite, the company's studio for avant-garde performing arts, and artists-in-residence/theater-training program, respectively; and for other related productions. Materials include: correspondence (see Series IB for additional production-specific correspondence); rights and royalties agreements; artist agreements and contracts; production descriptions and summaries; research material; script elements; artist and cast biographies; programs and program production elements (see Series II); press releases, flyers, and posters; press clippings and advertisements; grant applications and other development and fund-raising material; financial records including budgets, payrolls, receipts, checks, and box-office records; touring information; technical specifications; audio specifications and cue sheets; lighting plots, cue sheets, gels, and gobos; stage plots and schematics; costume and prop design and information; and some photographs (see Series IV).
Oversize material can be found in Boxes 21, 22 and in the map case.

Series IV: Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of Series IV is comprised of professionally produced 8"x10" black-and-white prints. Other size prints, contact sheets, negatives, color snapshots, and photographers' labels make up the rest of Series IV. Most prints and contact sheets are clearly marked with the photographer's name. For each folder in Series IV the photographer is listed directly below the name of the production, where applicable. Some folders contain the work of two or more photographers. In these folders the (un-labeled) negatives were rehoused in plastic sleeves, and the original labeled sleeve was retained and placed behind the negative. Oversize photographs are housed in Box 31. See Series IA, Box 2, Folder 82 for correspondence between Mabou Mines, photographers, and photo shops. Series III also contains some photographs.

did.unittitle: Subseries A: Production photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Documentary photographs of many Mabou Mines productions. Series is arranged alphabetically by production. Within each production the original order established by Mabou Mines was retained. Generally, this means the work of individual photographers is grouped, and prints usually appear before negatives or contact sheets. There is a semblance of chronology, though many photographs are undated.

Series VI: Scripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Scripts, drafts, notes, film treatments, and screenplays representing a majority of Mabou Mines' productions, and some Mabou Mines-affiliated productions. Of particular interest are the many drafts and early versions of Lee Breuer's works, scripts notated by Ruth Maleczech, and a monologue written by Samuel Beckett for David Warrilow.

did.unittitle: Series VII: Production Books

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series VII is made up of the contents of binders and folders that variously comprised scripts, notes, cues, contact sheets, schedules, and the like, usually heavily annotated, often compiled by a stage manager or director, for use during production of a play. Several Mabou Mines' productions, and some Mabou Mines-affiliated productions, are represented. Some folders contain scripts the company did not file with those scripts that make up Series VI. There is also significant overlap with Series III: Production Files. Of particular interest are the contents of binders used by JoAnne Akalaitis during production of the Dead End Kids film.

Series VIII: Touring Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p:
This series comprises records of Mabou Mines performances outside of New York City, including multi-state and international tours. The bulk of the series spans the 1980s into the early 1990s.
Subseries A contains files relating to specific performances or tours of specific productions. Cold Harbor is especially well-represented here, as this production toured extensively in the mid-1980s. Most of the folders in Subseries A contain some combination of the following materials: correspondence with representatives of a venue; tour schedules and itineraries; contact information of cast, crew, and venue; financial records including budgets; contracts; programs and flyers; lighting plots, track sheets, and cues; ground plans and stage schematics of various venues; maps and other travel information. The folders are arranged chronologically by performance date. The files within each folder may date to several months before and/or after the performance date. This arrangement clearly shows that it was not unusual for several Mabou Mines productions to tour simultaneously. There is significant overlap with the materials in Series III: Production Files, and this subseries can be compared with Series II: Programs for a more complete record of Mabou Mines performances.
Subseries B, General Touring Files, comprises similar material (correspondence, financial records, technical specifications, etc) related to no production in particular, or related to many different productions. This series is rich in what the company called "touring inquiries." Subseries C contains information on travel discounts including airline miles programs, and information on travel and lodging in specific cities. Subseries D contains Mabou Mines' collection of information on various national and international theater organizations and festivals, some in which Mabou Mines took part. These folders are arranged in alphabetical order by organization, then by festival.

did.unittitle: Paper ephemera from videotapes
Series X: Press

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series X contains numerous published articles written about Mabou Mines. There are original newspaper clippings, photocopies of clippings, magazine and journal articles, press releases, production histories, programs, and other related material. The material is arranged chronologically by subject. The series is divided into three subseries. The first part of Subseries A comprises pieces written about Mthe abou Mines company generally, and the second half comprises press about the company's awards and nominations. Subseries B is made up of press about individual company members and associates. The members are listed first, alphabetically, followed by the associates. Subseries C, the bulk of Series X, contains press and other material related to Mabou Mines productions and productions associated with Mabou Mines. The Mabou Mines plays are listed first, alphabetically by title, followed by the related productions.

When the collection was maintained by Mabou Mines, the newspaper reviews for some productions had been individually foldered and each given a rating based on its favorability. This rating system was expressed through the use of color-coded circle stickers attached to the tops of some folders. Rave reviews were given red or orange stickers, yellow stickers were for mixed reviews, and black were for negative reviews. Presumably, this enabled those working at Mabou Mines to quickly determine the general critical opinion of a given performance, and also served as a shortcut to finding reviews from which to pull quotes for press releases, advertisements, etc. This rating system was not retained when the collection was processed at Fales Library for the following reasons: (1) the researcher is better served if several reviews of a performance are collected into a single folder; (2) the rating system was not uniformly applied; (3) some colored stickers had fallen off before the series was processed; (4) a reader can distinguish a rave from a pan.

Subseries C: Productions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Articles and clippings about Mabou Mines productions are listed first, arranged alphabetically by title, then chronologically. Articles and other material about Mabou Mines-related productions are listed next. The designation "Beckett Plays" refers to any combination of Come and Go, The Lost Ones, and Play, which were often performed together in the company's early days. The company used this designation for the numerous published items that mention one or all of these plays, and it was retained for this series. Please note, however, that in other series each production is referred to by its individual title.

Series XI: Objects

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of objects and props from Mabou Mines productions. Of particular interest are the puppets Rose [ Shaggy Dog Animation] and John [ Prelude to Death in Venice], and the shadow puppets from the MahabharANTa.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The shadow puppets 133.2.0023 through 133.2.0053 were made for MahabharANTa, written by Lee Breuer and performed in 1992 in the United States. Larry Reed facilitated the collaboration between Lee Breuer and Balinese shadow master (dalang), I Wayan Wija. Wija made the rawhide puppets in 1992 in Bali. In an interview, he said he made all the puppets, except the wooden handles, which were custom-made by local artisans. Shadow puppets made of paper and found materials were not created by I Wayan Wija.
Source: Wija, I Wayan. 2023. Interview by Peiyuan Sun and Jessica Pace. WhatsApp. February 13, 2023.

did.unittitle: Rose--The Shaggy Dog Animation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: Rose, a puppet created by Linda Hartinian, measures 44" long, 15" wide, 6" deep, and is stored in box 319. Rose has long, dark brown hair and is dressed in a long-sleeved black jumpsuit with black corduroy shoes.

Rose's accessories include a painted head with two detachable wigs, a blue turtleneck and jeans, red sneakers and white socks, blue beaded elastic bands, a pink satin heart (all stored in box 320), a fur-lined denim jacket, a taxidermied paw, a gray sweatsuit, a black and metallic-colored kimono, beige satin cushions embroidered with red roses, and a beige satin band with velcro, and clear plastic poles used to control the puppet (all stored in box 321). Rose's costumes were created by Sally Rosen and Dru-ann Chukram.

Rose's head is double-sided, featuring two distinct faces. The first is painted a pale yellow-beige color with a long, wavy brown wig and the second face, directly on the other side, seemingly depicts an older woman. It has a slightly darker, more pink skin tone and a long, wavy gray wig. A wooden dowel is attached to the bottom of the double-sided head.
Rose's fur-lined denim jacket is split vertically along the back from the bottom hem to its collar to accommodate Rose's puppeteer.

did.unittitle: John--A Prelude to Death in Venice

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John the puppet measures 51" long, 19" wide, 8" deep, and is stored in box 322. The puppet has brown hair and is dressed in a navy blue knitted cap, a red scarf tied around the neck, light blue button down shirt, brown leather jacket, blue jeans, navy blue socks, and black leather shoes. John does not have arms or hands. In the play, the actor inserts their hands into John's sleeves and uses them as John's hands. John was designed and constructed by Linda Hartinian.

John's accessories include a navy blue knit beanie hat, a navy blue T-shirt with a boys' summer camp logo, a Kodak camera, a striped corduroy cushion, a beige band with a blue tie closure, and foam knee pads with velcro straps that were likely used by his puppeteer (all stored in box 323).

Series XII: Financial Files, Grants, and Development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content note
scopecontent.p: According to the existing arrangement of material, general financial files and grant material are chronologically ordered. Development files, however, were received in alphabetical order. The original arrangement has been preserved.

Distinctions between Financial Files, Grants and Development were provided originally by the company and have been upheld. Much of the content, however, defies strict differentiation. For example, some grant-related material may be found in a box labelled "Financial Files" or some general development papers may be found in "Grants."

Series XVI. Posters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of 108 posters from the Mabou Mines theater group, the majority of which are offset litho prints with a small number of electrostatic prints and photostats. Some posters show original mockup art with ink and graphite on board or with a thin tracing overlay. Posters are for performances of multiple Mabou Mines productions from the 1970s through the 1990s.
